data.headline: Which one am I?
couplets: You'll find me in the brush to the East,
hunting for a termite feast.
Other critters you'll see nearby,
have quills and feathers—but not I.
Look for me on the big red ledge,
I'm a little too close to the edge!
data.answerDetails: In Cherokee, I'm called ᎤᏯᏍᎦᎳ (uyasgatli). I'm known as a symbol of strong protection and healthy personal boundaries.

data.headline: Which one am I?
couplets: Everyone knows I'm great:
I'm the official wildflower of our state!
You may find me by a star of blue,
or near the tail of a cat, it's true.
If you'd like to see me even more,
go ask the rabbit at the front door.
data.answerDetails: My name comes from a Native American story about a girl lost in the forest who is kept warm by a blanket of red and yellow flowers.

data.headline: What color is my head?
couplets: Painted Bunting is my name,
My many colors are my fame!
My body has four different hues:
yellow, red, green, and blue.
Usually I try to hide from y'all
but today I'm out near the waterfall!
data.answerDetails: A traditional story explains that when the Great Spirit was giving birds their colors, the Painted Bunting was the last in line—so it just got leftovers.

data.headline: Which one am I?
couplets: What, haven't you heard?
I'm the Oklahoma state bird.
You can find me flying high,
above the herd, up in the sky.
I see a snake below me here,
And also, I see … a little blue deer?
data.answerDetails: In a Choctaw story, the Scissor-tailed Flycatcher was one of only two birds to survive a catastrophic flood, but the churning waters split its tail in half.

data.headline: How many are there?
couplets: If you look up (but not at high noon),
we're in the light of the hunter's moon.
After a story inside the cave walls,
gaze up to the sky as darkness falls.
From inside her den, Coyote can see,
and you can too—how many are we?
data.answerDetails: A Muscogee tale explains how the bat was given its teeth by other mammals during a ball game against the birds—so it could hold the ball!
